Subscribe to WSJ Pro Cybersecurity for in-depth coverage on cybersecurity trends, breaches and best practices. Good morning, CIOs. Microsoft Corp. will provide cloud services for the 17 U.S. intelligence agencies, the Washington Post reports . Executives say the deal better positions the company for a coming Pentagon cloud computing award worth billions of dollars, for which Amazon Web Services has been considered a favorite, the Post reports. The Pentagon contract, expected to be the largest Defense Department cloud-computing effort to date, is controversial because it awards work to a single company at a time when multi-cloud arrangements are on the rise.
How the intelligence deal came together. “The update came as part of a routine contract renewal between the Office of the Director of National Intelligence and computer provider Dell, which subcontracts government work to Microsoft,” the Post reports. “U.S. intelligence officials have not previously had access to the full suite of Microsoft Azure Government cloud services.”
The stakes. “The opportunity could amount to hundreds of millions of dollars as the 17 agencies that make up the U.S. intelligence community see more choices for data storage and analysis, though the exact amount will depend on how many orders are placed,” the Post reports.
Improving the odds of success for corporate transformations. Between the pace of technological innovation and the increasing integration of business ecosystems and global markets, the need for transformation has never been higher, says CIO Journal Columnist Irving Wladawsky-Berger .
TECHNOLOGY NEWS
An X-ray scan of the head of Kimberly Bari, who had a NeuroPace Responsive Neural Stimulator implanted in her brain to listen for and interrupt impending seizures. Photo: KIMBERLY BARI/UCSF
The AI doctor will see you now. Artificial intelligence in medicine promises to alert us to disease or a medical emergency before it happens—if only we can navigate the pitfalls. WSJ Tech Columnist Christopher Mims has more .
Data-privacy law creates new business for tech consultants. A cottage industry around privacy technology has sprung up in recent years, with firms offering new products and services designed to help companies more efficiently meet the demands of the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation. But experts tell the WSJ’s Natalia Drozdiak that some compliance tools could create additional legal risk for the companies using them.
Microsoft acquires conversational AI developer. Microsoft has bought Semantic Machines , a startup developing conversational artificial intelligence, CNBC reports . Semantic, based in Berkeley, uses machine learning to add context to conversations that people have with chatbots, taking information received by AI systems and applying it to future dialogue, according to CNBC.
Boston wants Amazon, But is there room? The possible arrival of Amazon.com Inc .’s second headquarters here is triggering both hopes and apprehension in a neighborhood already dealing with fallout from surging costs in a growing city, the WSJ’s Jon Kamp reports . And Boston isn’t alone: Most cities on Amazon’s shortlist of 20 finalists are grappling with the effects of gentrification and rising costs..
Employees say time-tracking systems chip away at paychecks. Workers at companies like American Airlines and Kroger Co. say employers are saving millions of dollars using time-tracking systems that automatically deduct pay for breaks and meals. The systems are capable of calculating employees’ pay to the second, the WSJ’s Rachel Feintzeig says , but employers are attracted to features like rounding and automatic time deductions because they help keep labor costs predictable.
Behind Ford’s new approach to advertising. Ford Motor Co. ’s No. 2 man Jim Farley tells the Journal’s John D. Stoll that the automaker is using digital platforms more and looking to new providers, including Netflix Inc., to produce its ads as the company rethinks how it allocates its $4 billion-plus advertising budget, and how much can be cut.
North Korea taps Google Play for spying. McAfee researchers say North Korea targeted defectors by posting to the Google Play store malware designed to steal data, including contact lists, ZDNet reports .
Apple makes first tax payment. Ireland’s financial minister Friday said the company paid $1.76 billion into an escrow account set up by the Irish government, Reuters reports . The account was set up to comply with a European Commission order calling upon Apple Inc. to pay the taxes it ruled it had received as illegal state aid.
Live from Brussels. When Mark Zuckerberg meets with European politicians Tuesday to discuss Facebook Inc. ‘s latest controveries, the proceedings will be live-streamed, Politico reports .
EVERYTHING ELSE YOU NEED TO KNOW
The Justice Department, on President Trump’s demand, asked its internal watchdog to examine if there was any impropriety in the counterintelligence investigation of his 2016 campaign . (WSJ)
Denise Morrison was the biggest champion of Campbell’s yearslong push into fresh and refrigerated foods , but her abrupt departure suggests that the strategy flopped. (WSJ).
The Treasury secretary and the administration’s top trade official took markedly different positions over whether the U.S. will move forward with tariffs on Chinese imports. (WSJ)
Global stocks rose as concerns about a trade war between the U.S. and China eased. (WSJ)
